section.title: Tying it All Together
section.para: In summary, there are several steps to creating a successful solution.

First, you configure the CentOS Studio build machine to accommodate the size and number of solutions you will build and store concurrently. The system should be accessible through your local network. After configuring the hardware, you can install one of the Linux operating system versions on which CentOS Studio runs.
Then you define your solution in the samba-server.definition file using XML tags defined in the SDFR. Your definition includes several key pieces of information:

listitem.para: the name of the solution, its version and architecture;
the repositories for the operating system and application packages, including base install and update mirror locations;
the package groups and packages to include and any packages to exclude; and

section.para: Once the solution definition is complete, you log on as the root user and execute the command centosstudio samba-server.definition to build the solution. Output goes to the screen and the default log file. The first build may take some time, since CentOS Studio needs to do everything from scratch:

file:///usr/share/doc/HTML/index.html
validate the samba-server.definition file,
locate input repositories,
create the configuration package,
resolve package dependencies,
download packages from input repositories,
create the solution (and it's metadata),
create network installation images, and
copy, or publish, solution content to a web-accessible location.
Deploying client machines requires two steps. First, you create the CD or DVD boot media. And then you install the client machine by inserting the disk into the client machine and later verifying that the contents are correct. Alternatively, you can use virt-manager or virt-install to deploy new virtual machines based on the solution.

Updating your solution can involve simply checking for mirror repository updates. Or it can involve changing the solution definition or configuration files and scripts. Depending upon the changes it encounters, CentOS Studio will update the solution as necessary. After updating the solution, you will need to run yum sync on client machines to keep them up to date with the current solution.

In the Samba CentOS 5 Server example presented here, what you have in the end is a solution for a Samba server on CentOS 5 for the i386 architecture. Your smb.conf file provides custom Samba configuration instructions. The packages come from the repositories at http://mirror.centos.org .
Now that you have your definition, you can prepare it for use in a production environment. The next chapter explains this process.
